trans-unit.source: Message Exchange Patterns for Bridges
trans-unit.target: Message Exchange Patterns for Bridges

trans-unit.source: Bridges being message intermediaries between the clients and services, they must support the different message exchange patterns agreed upon between the respective clients and services.
trans-unit.target: Bridges being message intermediaries between the clients and services, they must support the different message exchange patterns agreed upon between the respective clients and services.

trans-unit.source: Currently, the <token>xml_bridge</token> supports two message exchange patterns – <token>one-way</token> and <token>request_response</token>.
trans-unit.target: Currently, the <token>xml_bridge</token> supports two message exchange patterns – <token>one-way</token> and <token>request_response</token>.

trans-unit.source: <token>passthru</token> also supports only one-way message exchange pattern.
trans-unit.target: <token>passthru</token> also supports only one-way message exchange pattern.

trans-unit.source: Note that the message exchange patterns are considered at the application level, which means, that for a <token>request_response</token>, the client sending a message to the service expects a response back.
trans-unit.target: Note that the message exchange patterns are considered at the application level, which means, that for a <token>request_response</token>, the client sending a message to the service expects a response back.

trans-unit.source: For <token>one-way</token>, no such response is expected.
trans-unit.target: For <token>one-way</token>, no such response is expected.

trans-unit.source: In an <token>one-way</token>, the client sends a message to the service but does not expect or request a response back.
trans-unit.target: In an <token>one-way</token>, the client sends a message to the service but does not expect or request a response back.

trans-unit.source: An <token>one-way</token> contains the following stages:
trans-unit.target: An <token>one-way</token> contains the following stages:

trans-unit.source: Validate
trans-unit.target: Validate

trans-unit.source: Enrich, pre-transform
trans-unit.target: Enrich, pre-transform

trans-unit.source: Transform
trans-unit.target: Transform

trans-unit.source: Enrich, post-transform
trans-unit.target: Enrich, post-transform

trans-unit.source: See <link xlink:href="3e49765d-97e5-407e-9d9c-698060c0249e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Uses and Stages of XML Bridges</link>.
trans-unit.target: See <link xlink:href="3e49765d-97e5-407e-9d9c-698060c0249e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Uses and Stages of XML Bridges</link>.

trans-unit.source: Constraints on Using an XML One-Way Bridge
trans-unit.target: Constraints on Using an XML One-Way Bridge

trans-unit.source: An <token>one-way</token> can route messages to any destination that can be added to a <token>msgflow_proj</token>.
trans-unit.target: An <token>one-way</token> can route messages to any destination that can be added to a <token>msgflow_proj</token>.

trans-unit.source: The only consideration is that when you route a message from a <token>one-way</token> to two-way destination endpoints, such as Two-Way Relay Endpoint, Two-Way External Service Endpoint, or an <token>request_response</token>, then the response message that is received from any of these two-way endpoints is ignored by the <token>one-way</token>.
trans-unit.target: The only consideration is that when you route a message from a <token>one-way</token> to two-way destination endpoints, such as Two-Way Relay Endpoint, Two-Way External Service Endpoint, or an <token>request_response</token>, then the response message that is received from any of these two-way endpoints is ignored by the <token>one-way</token>.

trans-unit.source: In an <token>request_response</token>, the client sends a message to the service and expects a response back.
trans-unit.target: In an <token>request_response</token>, the client sends a message to the service and expects a response back.

trans-unit.source: Request Path
trans-unit.target: Request Path

trans-unit.source: The request path of the bridge contains the following stages:
trans-unit.target: The request path of the bridge contains the following stages:

trans-unit.source: Validate
trans-unit.target: Validate

trans-unit.source: Enrich, pre-transform
trans-unit.target: Enrich, pre-transform

trans-unit.source: Transform
trans-unit.target: Transform

trans-unit.source: Enrich, post-transform
trans-unit.target: Enrich, post-transform

trans-unit.source: Reply Path
trans-unit.target: Reply Path

trans-unit.source: The response path of the bridge contains the following stages:
trans-unit.target: The response path of the bridge contains the following stages:

trans-unit.source: Enrich, pre-transform
trans-unit.target: Enrich, pre-transform

trans-unit.source: Transform
trans-unit.target: Transform

trans-unit.source: Enrich, post-transform
trans-unit.target: Enrich, post-transform

trans-unit.source: Reply Action
trans-unit.target: Reply Action

trans-unit.source: For more information about each of these stages, see <link xlink:href="3e49765d-97e5-407e-9d9c-698060c0249e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Uses and Stages of XML Bridges</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about each of these stages, see <link xlink:href="3e49765d-97e5-407e-9d9c-698060c0249e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Uses and Stages of XML Bridges</link>.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Reply Action, see <link xlink:href="2b28ccb0-dd88-4fbc-a5c4-c3b797a901e8" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Send Action: Send a Response Back to the Client</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Reply Action, see <link xlink:href="2b28ccb0-dd88-4fbc-a5c4-c3b797a901e8" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Send Action: Send a Response Back to the Client</link>.

trans-unit.source: Constraints on Using an XML Request-Reply Bridge
trans-unit.target: Constraints on Using an XML Request-Reply Bridge

trans-unit.source: You can use an <token>request_response</token> only for routing messages to two-way relay endpoints, two-way external service endpoints, or other <token>request_response</token>.
trans-unit.target: You can use an <token>request_response</token> only for routing messages to two-way relay endpoints, two-way external service endpoints, or other <token>request_response</token>.

trans-unit.source: In a <token>passthru</token>, the client sends a message of any message type to the bridge and does not expect a response back.
trans-unit.target: In a <token>passthru</token>, the client sends a message of any message type to the bridge and does not expect a response back.

trans-unit.source: A <token>passthru</token> contains only an Enrich stage and is only a one-way bridge.
trans-unit.target: A <token>passthru</token> contains only an Enrich stage and is only a one-way bridge.

trans-unit.source: Constraints on Using a Pass-Through Bridge
trans-unit.target: Constraints on Using a Pass-Through Bridge

trans-unit.source: The constraints for a <token>passthru</token> are same as the constraints for an <token>one-way</token>.
trans-unit.target: The constraints for a <token>passthru</token> are same as the constraints for an <token>one-way</token>.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link xlink:href="300b4e72-27f3-4526-a3cd-44f00a8b7a53#BKMK_ConstOneWay" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Constraints on Using an XML One-Way Bridge</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link xlink:href="300b4e72-27f3-4526-a3cd-44f00a8b7a53#BKMK_ConstOneWay" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Constraints on Using an XML One-Way Bridge</link>.
